titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Franklin Toker Papers, 1964-2017 UA.90.F108
titlestmt.author: Cassidee Knott.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 10:12:57 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Franklin Toker is an architectural historian, professor, and author best known for his work on Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater, Pittsburgh architecture, and the Duomo in Florence, Italy. This collection includes materials pertaining to Toker's research, publications, and teaching and professional activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Franklin Toker Papers span the entire career of the architect, author, and professor. Much of the collection consists of research and drafts of several of his publications, including The Church of Notre-Dame in Montreal, Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait, Fallingwater Rising, and his multi-volume Florence Duomo Project. Also included are research files on the Carnegie Museum of Natural History's Hall of Architecture, general research files, course materials, and professional correspondence.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Franklin Toker was born in 1944 in Montreal, Canada. He studied Fine Arts at McGill University, completing his undergraduate studies in 1964. He next attended Oberlin College, receiving a Master's degree in History of Art in 1966 and his Ph.D. in Fine Arts from Harvard University in 1973. After earning his doctorate, Toker taught at several schools, including Boston School of Architecture, Dartmouth College in Florence, and Carnegie Mellon University, before ultimately arriving at the University of Pittsburgh as a professor of History of Art and Architecture in 1987. He also lectured abroad in countries like Italy, Canada, India, and Japan.

Toker has written eleven books, most notably his volumes on the Florence Duomo Project, Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait, Fallingwater Rising, and The Church of Notre-Dame in Montreal. His work on the Florence Duomo Project is made up of 4 books: On Holy Ground: Liturgy, Architecture, and Urbanism in the Cathedral and the Streets of Medieval Florence; Archaeological Campaigns below the Florence Duomo and Baptistry; Reconstructing the Cathedral and Baptistry of Florence in Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages; and When Stones Speak: The Florence Duomo Excavations in the Light of History. In the process of writing these books, Toker participated in two archaeological digs in Florence, one of them being at the famous Cathedral of Saint Maria del Fiore. Toker also took an interest in architecture local to him in Pittsburgh. He completed extensive research on Pittsburgh neighborhoods, buildings, and industries, which contributed to several of his books.

Over the course of his career, Toker received many awards and accolades. Toker was the president of the Society of Architectural Historians in 1992. He was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton University, as well as a Guggenheim and National Endowment for the Humanities fellow. For his writing, Toker received the Alice Davis Hitchcock Award of the Society of Architectural Historians in 1970, and the Porter Prize of the College Art Association in 1978. In November 2017, Toker was named a Distinguished Professor of the University of Pittsburgh.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Israel Heritage Room Committee Collection, 1929-2013, UA.40.13, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Cassidee Knott in February 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Franklin Toker Papers, 1964-2017, UA.90.F108, University Archives, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Franklin Toker in May 2018.

unittitle.title: The Church of Notre-Dame in Montreal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of research conducted by Dr. Frank Toker for his 1970 book The Church of Notre-Dame in Montreal: An Architectural History. A second edition of the book was published in 1991. The research consists of correspondence regarding the book and building, lectures given by Dr. Toker about the Cathedral, photographs of the building used in the book, and other articles about the Cathedral and its construction. This series also contains a copy of the 1970 edition of the completed book.

unittitle.title: The Church of Notre-Dame in Montreal: An Architectural History
Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains research files and drafts of Dr. Toker's 1986 book, Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait, and its 2009 revised edition, Pittsburgh: A New Portrait. The books analyze the urban setting of Pittsburgh and the ways in which Pittsburgh has changed over time. These changes are reflected in research files about Pittsburgh and western Pennsylvania buildings, neighborhoods, and industries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries mainly contains research on Pittsburgh buildings, neighborhoods, and industry. It also contains drafts of the first edition of the book at various stages.

unittitle.title: Pittsburgh: A New Portrait

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily contains neighborhood and general research. The general research files explore Pittsburgh's development since the 1980s to identify changes between the 1986 edition and 2008. The subseries also contains photos of Pittsburgh.

unittitle.title: Fallingwater Rising

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 2003, Dr. Toker published Fallingwater Rising: Frank Lloyd Wright, E. J. Kaufmann, and America's Most Extraordinary House. This series contains book drafts, research files, correspondence, lectures, and other publications that focus on specific aspects of the book and Fallingwater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of both early and edited drafts of the Fallingwater Rising book. Also present are illustrations, chapter openers, and a copy of the completed book.

did.unittitle: Fallingwater Rising: Epilogue, Acknowledgments, Index, Sources

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries is made up of articles regarding Fallingwater authored by Toker during his extensive research on the house. These articles either contributed to or aided in the research for his Fallingwater Rising book.

unittitle.title: Making Fallingwater Rising

did.unittitle: The Most Famous House in the World draft by Franklin Toker
The Most Famous House in the World draft by Franklin Toker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images and other media in this subseries include photographs of Fallingwater, as well as other locations affiliated with Frank Lloyd Wright. Such photos have been used in research for and the production of Fallingwater Rising. Also included are proofs of the book jacket design. There are some photos that are not identified.

did.unittitle: Fallingwater Photos used in Fallingwater Rising
Photos of Blueprints, Drawings, and Newspapers
Xeroxes of Final Photo Selection for Fallingwater Rising

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the extensive research done for the Fallingwater Rising book. These files pertain to such subjects as the house itself, the Kaufmann family, Frank Lloyd Wright, and the geographic area. Several of these files include copies of archival material from other repositories.

did.unittitle: Student Report on Phenomenon of Fallingwater

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain the text of several lectures presented by Dr. Toker pertaining to various aspects of Fallingwater, as well as notes on the 1999 Fallingwater Seminar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries holds research and publication related correspondence pertaining to Fallingwater Rising.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the vast amount of research and writing completed by Dr. Toker on the Duomo in Florence, Italy. Included are drafts of the first two volumes of the project. The first, On Holy Ground: Liturgy, Architecture and Urbanism in the Cathedral and the Streets of Medieval Florence, covers the origins of the Duomo's architecture and was published in 2009. The second book is titled Archaeological Campaigns Below the Florence Duomo and Baptistery, 1895-1980, which covers the excavations below Santa Maria del Fiore and was published in 2012. There is also information about the other two volumes, Reconstructing the Cathedral and Baptistery of Florence in Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages and When Stones Speak: The Florence Duomo Excavations in the Light of History. In addition to writing drafts, this series also contains research files and correspondence.

unittitle.title: On Holy Ground: Liturgy, Architecture and Urbanism in the Cathedral and the Streets of Medieval Florence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries details the first book of the Florence Duomo Project volumes, which looks into the origins of the architecture and design of the Cathedral. Included in this subseries are the book's appendices and a variety of drafts of the first volume.

did.unittitle: Appendix I and II On Holy Ground Draft

unittitle.title: Archaeological Campaigns Below the Florence Duomo and Baptistery, 1895-1980

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains two drafts of the second volume in the Duomo series, which pertains to the excavations and findings at Santa Maria del Fiore in Florence, Italy.

unittitle.title: Reconstructing the Cathedral and Baptistery of Florence in Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains four drafts of the third volume of the Florence Duomo Project, which details the architecture of the Duomo by exploring its historical context.

did.unittitle: Santa Reparata: The Architectural History Full Draft

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These files contain three drafts of the fourth and final book of the Florence Duomo Project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries is a collection of preliminary research drafts and articles pertaining to a variety of themes from the Florence Duomo Project books. Much of the information in these publications was either built upon or used as research for Dr. Toker's books.

scopecontent.p: These files contain the various research articles, photographs, architectural drawings, and notes used to produce the Florence Duomo Project books. The files have maintained their original titles and are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The correspondence in this subseries pertains to the development and progress of the Florence Duomo Project. Included are letters from people at the University of Pittsburgh, as well as architectural historians and others with interest in the project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Florence architect Arnolfo di Cambio designed aspects of the Duomo at the end of the thirteenth century. These research files pertaining to di Cambio's designs and contributions to the Duomo were intended to be used by Dr. Toker for a book on the architect's career.

unittitle.title: Alfonso Di Cambio the Beginnings of Artistic Identity
Archeologia Medievale
Arte d'Occidente temi e metodi

did.unittitle: Cesta Internation Center of Medieval Art

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists mostly of photographs and research on the architecture of the casts in the Carnegie Museum of Natural History's Hall of Architecture. This research was used to write a 2013 feasibility study to restore the room and the casts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These research files on Pittsburgh topics and ancient synagogues were compiled for unspecified or never completed projects. Included are articles, photographs, and other resources pertaining to architectural topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains research files on specific architects that have made substantial contributions to the Pittsburgh urban landscape, as well as more general information about Pittsburgh history and buildings. Also included are files on projects that had not been published, "Pittsburgh Transformed" and "Lords of Pittsburgh."

did.unittitle: Bibliography/ Research Method/ Sources in Pittsburgh Architecture
Images of Pittsburgh in Art and Photos
PPG Place, Styles in Pittsburgh, and Miscellaneous Building and Information
Toker Minor Articles on Pittsburgh, "Lords of Pittsburgh" Project
Toker Minor Articles on Pittsburgh, "Lords of Pittsburgh" Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Dr. Toker's research on ancient Jewish architecture and synagogues. While the intent of the research is not specified, it is likely that some of this material was used for his proposed design of the Israel Heritage Nationality Room in the Cathedral of Learning at the University of Pittsburgh.

did.unittitle: Ancient Jewish Architecture Research and Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series pertains to numerous lectures and seminars given by Dr. Toker over the course of his career at the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie Mellon University. Topics include Architecture in the Nineteenth Century; Gothic Architecture in Northern Europe; Introduction to the History of Art; and the Romanesque Seminar, among others. Included are source books of articles, lecture notes, syllabi, and research for the courses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains incoming and outgoing correspondence from throughout Dr. Toker's career as a professor and author. These records also include letters from his time as president of the Society of Architectural Historians. Some correspondence is in Italian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Personal Correspondence subseries is made up of personal letters to and from Dr. Toker and family, friends and colleagues discussing a variety of topics from 1978 to 2010. This subseries also includes several journals kept by Dr. Toker during the 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Professional Correspondence subseries is a collection of professional letters both to and from Dr. Toker over the course of his career. Those corresponding with Toker include professors at the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie Mellon, as well as other collegues from abroad. This subseries also includes reports, course information, news clippings, calendars, and curriculum vitae. Also present is information pertaining to the publishing of several of Dr. Toker's books, including Pittsburgh: An Urban Portrait and Fallingwater Rising.

did.unittitle: Art and Execution of the Israel Room
"A Question of Grit: Five Days on the Pittsburgh to Washington Bike Trail"
General Correspondence on the Israel Room
Professional Correspondence, HAA Department and Mini-notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Society of Architectural Historians Correspondence subseries consists of letters both to and from Dr. Toker regarding the Society of Architectural Historians, a group to which Toker was a member and former president. Also included as attachments are meeting minutes, notes, and information on SAH conferences.
